_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The following executive summary is required by Regulation Part 68, Subpart 6, 68.150, and has been included in the electronic submittal of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) to the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The areas addressed in the executive summary are covered in greater detail in the remainder of the RMP.  Appendix A contains a copy of the electronically submitted site registration to EPA and Appendix B contains a copy of the toxic endpoint maps and data.

1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source

Catenary Coal Company (Catenary) has policies and procedures that have trained their employees in the safe handling, storage and use of anhydrous ammonia.  Employees are also trained in emergency response procedures to prevent and/or mitigate the accidental release of anhydrous ammonia at this facility.

The equipment used in the transportation, storage and use of anhydrous ammonia conform to the appropriate federal and state regulations dealing with this material.  Equipment and maintenance records are kept in company files.  Catenary uses qualified third party contractors to transport anhydrous ammonia to this facility.  Company personnel and/or independent safety consultants provide additional training in safety and emergency procedures for Catenary.

Catenary has coordinated its emergency response procedures with the Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC).

2.    Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handling

There are two stationary sources covered by this RMP.  The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia.  The tank capacities are 10,000 and 1,000 gallons.  The tanks are not filled to a volume greater than 85 percent of total capacity.

3.    Worse Case and Alternative Scenarios Including Administration Controls and Mitigation Measures to Limit Discharge Distances

 
Catenary has performed a hazard assessment of its operations and established that the worse case scenario release of anhyd

rous ammonia would result from the catastrophic failure of both storage tanks filled to 85 percent of capacity.  For this worse case scenario discharge, no administrative controls or mitigation measures were considered to limit the anticipated toxic endpoint of the regulated material.  EPA=s RMP Comp program was used to establish toxic endpoint data in the worse case scenario.  The worse case release scenario has established the toxic endpoint will extend away from the source radially for 3.4 miles.

Catenary has performed a hazard assessment of its operations and established that the alternative release scenario for anhydrous ammonia most likely to result in a toxic release would occur from the failure of a transfer hose during the transfer of the regulated material from a bulk tanker truck to a storage tank.  For the alternative release scenario, Catenary considered the effects of passive mitigation systems such as the excess flow valves and the active mitigation measures initiated by employees monitoring the material transfer that will limit the duration and amount of material release to volumes below the capacity of both the tanker and storage tank.  The toxic endpoint for the alternative release scenario is 0.4 miles radially from the source, according to the RMP Comp program.

4.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical - Specific Prevention Steps

The storage tanks are equipped with passive mitigation devices.  Excess flow valves are designed to prevent the rapid loss of regulated material through piping.  The buildup of excess pressure is released through pop-off valves.

Transfer operations between bulk trucks and storage tanks are monitored by trained personnel.  Employees and contractors have been trained as to the properly handling and hazards of anhydrous ammonia.  Storage containers are properly labeled and hazard warnings are posted.  Employees working with anhydrous ammonia have been provided with the appropriate personal protective

equipment.

5.    Five Year Accident History

None.

6.    Emergency Response Program

In the event of a reportable release of anhydrous ammonia, Catenary employees have been trained to assess the dangers presented by the release, take immediate reactions to mitigate the release (when possible) or evacuate the area, don personal protective equipment, communicate with off-site company personnel and contact the local authorities and LEPC.

 
7.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Catenary will mark the discharge point of the anhydrous ammonia.
